columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the amount that we will have after $40$ years based on the given parameters using the concept of growing annuity and future value annuity.

Since the deposits will start the following year, the salary would already have increased by $3\%$ based on the given problem. We can now solve for how much the salary is at the end of that year.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{New salary}&=\$55,000 \times (1+0.03)\\[15 pt]
&=\$56,650
\end{aligned}$$

The new salary is now $\$56,650$.

Now that we have the salary for next year, we will solve for the amount that will be deposited. It is indicated in the problem that $9\%$ of the salary will be deposited every year.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Deposit}&=\$56,650 \times 0.09\\[15 pt]
&=\$5,098.50
\end{aligned}$$

At the end of next year, the deposit will be $\$5,098.50$

Now that we have the deposit, we can solve for the growing annuity by substituting the value to the formula in Step 2:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Growing annuity}&=\$5,098.50 \times\dfrac{1-\left(\frac{1+0.03}{1+0.10}\right)^{40}}{0.10-0.03}\\[15 pt]
&=\$67,586.12
\end{aligned}$$

The growing annuity value of the deposit is $\$67,586.12$

We can now substitute the values that we have to the formula in Step 6. For the cash flow, we will use the growing annuity of the deposit.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Future value annuity}&=\$67,586.12 \times (1+0.10)^{40}\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,058,897.48
\end{aligned}$$

The future value of the savings after $40$ years is $\$3,058,897.48$
